dialogue_turns.speaker: AgentA
dialogue_turns.text: Kazakhstan's PISA scores, they've actually gone up from 380 to 400 since 2012.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Kazakhstan's P I S A scores, they've actually gone up from three hundred eighty to four hundred since twenty twelve.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Compared to 2009 our 15-year-old students reading results lowered from 390 to 387 scores which is considered non statistically significant.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: That's a statistically significant jump, right? But it's still way below the OECD average of 470—that's like a whole school year behind.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: That's a statistically significant jump, right? But it's still way below the O E C D average of four hundred seventy-that's like a whole school year behind.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Compared to 2009 our 15-year-old students reading results lowered from 390 to 387 scores which is considered non statistically significant. But compared to average OECD scores of 487, it equals to more than two-school-year difference.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. And when you look at reading literacy rankings, Kazakhstan is 20th out of 77 countries. So there's progress, but the education system itself might not be the main driver here.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly. And when you look at reading literacy rankings, Kazakhstan is twentieth out of seventy seven countries. So there's progress, but the education system itself might not be the main driver here.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: When it comes to reading literacy, Kazakhstan is the 9th last out of 77 countries.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, Aliya Bizhanova points out that when she surveys teachers and principals in Astana, she's impressed if they write without errors—it suggests broader literacy improvement beyond just schools.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, Aliya Bizhanova points out that when she surveys teachers and principals in Astana, she's impressed if they write without errors-it suggests broader literacy improvement beyond just schools.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: When I read their survey results, I am shocked if a teacher or principal of Almaty city school writes with errors what can we say about overall reading literacy of young people or general public?

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: But she's also clear that it's not just about education. The OECD data shows no real link between the number of books at home and student literacy.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But she's also clear that it's not just about education. The O E C D data shows no real link between the number of books at home and student literacy.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: OECD results show, that there is direct link between decreasing number of books at home and students literacy level.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Right, the reading culture really starts with family habits. Like, if a parent reads to their five-year-old, that's where the habit forms.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, the reading culture really starts with family habits. Like, if a parent reads to their five-year-old, that's where the habit forms.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The culture of reading is not being born in school, it becomes a habit when a mother or father read to their child when he or she is one-year-old or younger.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: But how much time does the average Kazakhstani family actually spend reading? She mentions seeing parents glued to their phones—not books or even children's fairy tales.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But how much time does the average Kazakhstani family actually spend reading? She mentions seeing parents glued to their phones-not books or even children's fairy tales.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: How much time does a regular Kazakhstani family spend on reading? I see a lot of parents with mobile phones, there are TVs, cartoons and video games on a lot at home.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: It's interesting though—in Canada, they give books to families during clinic visits for one-year-olds. That kind of encouragement is missing here.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It's interesting though-in Canada, they give books to families during clinic visits for one-year-olds. That kind of encouragement is missing here.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: For example, to encourage family reading time, 9-month old baby and his/her parents in Great Britain are provided books during outpatients clinic visit.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: And UNESCO says there's no direct correlation between libraries and literacy rates, which is surprising. But she argues our libraries are actually doing better than people think.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And UNESCO says there's no direct correlation between libraries and literacy rates, which is surprising. But she argues our libraries are actually doing better than people think.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: UNESCO results show that there is direct correlation between libraries and populations reading literacy. Everyone in the country knows what conditions our public libraries are in.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, she works from district libraries sometimes and says about twenty people visit daily just to read or borrow books—which she finds impressive.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, she works from district libraries sometimes and says about twenty people visit daily just to read or borrow books-which she finds impressive.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Based on my experience, do you know how many people visit a library to read or take/return books? You will be shocked, but it is usually one or two people maximum.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Compared to libraries abroad, which she describes as boring, dark buildings with no events or e-resources, ours have bright rooms, new collections, and a modern environment since 2010.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Compared to libraries abroad, which she describes as boring, dark buildings with no events or e-resources, ours have bright rooms, new collections, and a modern environment since twenty ten.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Libraries in developed countries are considered centers of districts called Community Centers, where interesting events take place for adults and kids - there is entertaining environment where books and journals are interesting to read, there are great e-library resources, public events, play time, there is light and open space. How about our libraries? There are dark rooms with dusty stacks of books.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: So it's frustrating when funding goes to things like Expo exhibitions or replacing curbs in Astana instead of supporting these thriving libraries.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So it's frustrating when funding goes to things like Expo exhibitions or replacing curbs in Astana instead of supporting these thriving libraries.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: It then makes more sense to invest in local libraries and in their transformation, rather than to spend huge amounts of money on Expo exhibition or new curbs that are regularly replaced in Almaty city.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. If we want to attract more families, including kids, investing in libraries makes more sense than those big flashy projects.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly. If we want to attract more families, including kids, investing in libraries makes more sense than those big flashy projects.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: It's about changing habits early and making reading accessible—not just at school, but everywhere.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It's about changing habits early and making reading accessible-not just at school, but everywhere.

artist_script:
AgentA: Kazakhstan's PISA scores, they've actually gone up from 380 to 400 since 2012.
HostB: That's a statistically significant jump, right? But it's still way below the OECD average of 470—that's like a whole school year behind.
HostA: Exactly. And when you look at reading literacy rankings, Kazakhstan is 20th out of 77 countries. So there’s progress, but the education system itself might not be the main driver here.
HostB: Yeah, Aliya Bizhanova points out that when she surveys teachers and principals in Astana, she’s impressed if they write without errors—it suggests broader literacy improvement beyond just schools.
HostA: But she’s also clear that it’s not just about education. The OECD data shows no real link between the number of books at home and student literacy.
HostB: Right, the reading culture really starts with family habits. Like, if a parent reads to their five-year-old, that’s where the habit forms.
HostA: But how much time does the average Kazakhstani family actually spend reading? She mentions seeing parents glued to their phones—not books or even children’s fairy tales.
HostB: It’s interesting though—in Canada, they give books to families during clinic visits for one-year-olds. That kind of encouragement is missing here.
HostA: And UNESCO says there’s no direct correlation between libraries and literacy rates, which is surprising. But she argues our libraries are actually doing better than people think.
HostB: Yeah, she works from district libraries sometimes and says about twenty people visit daily just to read or borrow books—which she finds impressive.
HostA: Compared to libraries abroad, which she describes as boring, dark buildings with no events or e-resources, ours have bright rooms, new collections, and a modern environment since 2010.
HostB: So it’s frustrating when funding goes to things like Expo exhibitions or replacing curbs in Astana instead of supporting these thriving libraries.
HostA: Exactly. If we want to attract more families, including kids, investing in libraries makes more sense than those big flashy projects.
HostB: It’s about changing habits early and making reading accessible—not just at school, but everywhere.
